title: Identifying Cognitive Distortions
summary: Learn to spot unhelpful thinking patterns that distort reality and fuel negative emotions.

details.content: Cognitive distortions are automatic, biased ways of thinking that can worsen anxiety, depression, and stress. Recognizing them is the first step to changing them.
You think, 'I always mess things up,' after making a small mistake at work. This is an example of all-or-nothing thinking.

content: Keep a daily log of negative thoughts and label the distortion (e.g., catastrophizing, mind reading).
Review a list of common distortions to familiarize yourself.
Ask yourself: Is this thought an example of a known distortion?

title: Examining the Evidence
summary: Challenge negative thoughts by weighing the real evidence for and against them.

details.content: Negative thoughts often feel true but are not always based on facts. Examining evidence helps you develop a more balanced perspective.
You think, 'Nobody likes me.' You list evidence for (e.g., someone didn’t reply to a text) and against (e.g., a friend invited you to lunch).

content: Write down the thought and list all supporting and contradicting evidence.
Ask yourself: What would I tell a friend in this situation?
Look for objective facts, not feelings.

title: Reattribution
summary: Shift away from blaming yourself for everything by considering other possible causes.

details.content: People often take excessive responsibility for negative events, which can increase guilt and low self-esteem. Reattribution helps you see the bigger picture.
You blame yourself for a team project’s failure. On reflection, you note that unclear instructions and tight deadlines also played a role.

content: Ask: What else might have contributed to this situation?
Consider external factors and other people’s roles.
Remind yourself that most outcomes have multiple causes.

title: Decatastrophizing
summary: Reduce anxiety by realistically assessing how bad a feared outcome would actually be.

details.content: Catastrophic thinking exaggerates how terrible things will be, fueling anxiety and avoidance. Decatastrophizing helps you see that you can cope.
You fear, 'If I make a mistake, I’ll get fired and never find another job.' You break it down and realize this is unlikely and that you have resources to cope.

content: Ask: What’s the worst that could happen? How likely is it?
What would I do if the worst happened?
What’s the most likely outcome? What’s the best that could happen?

title: Cognitive Reframing
summary: Find more balanced or positive ways to interpret situations and thoughts.

details.content: Reframing helps you move away from negative automatic thoughts and see situations from a healthier, more constructive perspective.
Instead of thinking, 'I failed,' you reframe it as, 'I learned something valuable for next time.'

content: Ask: Is there another way to look at this?
What would I say to a friend in this situation?
Practice finding at least one alternative explanation for negative thoughts.

title: Behavioral Experiments
summary: Test the accuracy of your thoughts by trying out new behaviors and observing the results.

details.content: Behavioral experiments help you gather real-life evidence to challenge unhelpful beliefs, reducing their power over time.
You believe, 'If I speak up in meetings, people will think I’m stupid.' You try speaking up and notice that people respond positively.

content: Identify a belief to test and plan a small experiment.
Predict what you think will happen.
Try the behavior and record what actually happens.

title: Thought Records
summary: Use structured worksheets to track situations, thoughts, emotions, and alternative responses.

details.content: Thought records help you systematically analyze and challenge negative thoughts, making cognitive restructuring more concrete and effective.
After a stressful event, you fill out a thought record: situation, automatic thought, emotion, evidence for/against, and a more balanced thought.

content: Use a template or app to record thoughts daily.
Include situation, thought, emotion, evidence, and alternative thought.
Review your records weekly to spot patterns and progress.
